awd_titl_txt: In-situ Atomic-Scale Observation on Interface Formation and Friction
awd_abstract_narration:
Friction between two solid surfaces in contact with relative lateral motion is an important consideration in mechanical machine processes. The ongoing miniaturization of micro electro-mechanical systems and magnetic storage devices has elevated the importance of friction, because it plays an outsized role in reduction of the lifetime and stability of the micro electro-mechanical system and increases its energy-consumption and emissions. The conventional friction laws based on continuum mechanic models are no longer adequate to describe the frictional behaviors of nanometer-sized contacts in which the position and dynamics of discrete atoms play important roles in determining local sliding process.  This research will develop a new methodology for studying atomic friction by in situ high resolution transmission electron microscopy to observe the atomic-scale frictional processes between metallic contacts. The research findings will provide new insights to the origin of atomic friction between metallic contacts, and provide knowledge that can be applied for improving the design and reliability of micro electro-mechanical devices, benefiting U.S. industries and the economy. The PI will integrate research and education, training graduate and undergraduate students with diverse demographic backgrounds, particularly female and other members of underrepresented groups, and providing opportunities for them to gain experience in national laboratories.

Nanotribology studies can lead to insights that directly impact the performance and reliability of microelectro-mechanical systems (MEMS) and magnetic storage devices. The rapid miniaturization of these devices raises an increasing demand to understand and control atomic friction. Atomic friction has mainly been studied by atomic-force microscopy (AFM) and computer-based simulations, where counter motion between the AFM tip and the substrate surface is generally found to proceed in a "stick-slip" manner accompanied by sawtooth-like friction forces commensurate with the period of substrate lattice. Such a classic ?stick-slip? friction behavior has been observed on various surfaces. By contrast, super-lubricity featured by continuous sliding and constantly trivial friction forces has occasionally been found between atomically incommensurate surfaces. Yet, the atomistic mechanisms giving rise to this very low friction are still under extensive debate. A critical characteristic impeding understanding of the underlying mechanisms governing friction is the complex nature of the atomically rough contacting interface that mostly consists of nanoscopic asperities. Achieving a mechanistic understanding of atomic friction thus requires information on real-time interfacial structure of single-asperity sliding contacts, which is unfortunately beyond the capability of most existing experimental methods, including AFM-based techniques which is the most widely applied experimental method for studying nano-/atomic-scale friction.  This research is to perform concurrent in-situ atomic-scale observation and friction force measurements during countermotion between nanosized single-asperity contacts and reveal the significant impact of the interfacial structure on frictional performances. The research is expected to significantly advance the fundamental understanding of atomic frictional behaviors, and provide important guidelines for improving the design and reliability of MEMS devices. The novel experiments on in-situ transmission electron microscope is expected to open a new avenue for direct observation of atomistic friction processes, and also will enrich tribology and friction theories at atomic scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Micro-/nano-electromechanical systems, composed of both electronic and moving parts, have many technologically significant applications in wireless communication, biomedical diagnostics, sensing, and energy harvesting. Reducing friction on the atomic-scale is crucial for improving the performance and reliability of these micro-/nano-electromechanical systems with a high surface/volume ratio. Nevertheless, the mechanisms of atomic friction behavior on interfaces are still elusive, primarily due to a lack of direct observation of the contacting interface during frictional process. This award supports research to acquire fundamental knowledge of interface formation and friction processes between two metallic asperities under normal forces using the state-of-the-art in situ high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and advanced computational method such as molecular dynamics (MD).  To accomplish this objective, we have in situ processed the single-asperity nanometer-contacts between two crystals of W/Au, Mo/Au, W/W and W/Mo with desired viewing and loading crystallographic directions, carried out atomic friction experiment on the single-asperity nano-contacts by applying shear force at room temperature inside the HRTEM, captured the real-time friction motion between single asperities at atomic resolution, and performed the atomistic MD simulations to gain understanding of the observed processes. Moreover, we have extended the developed HRTEM technology to directly observe the formation and annihilation processes of a high angle grain boundary in gold (Au) under the bending loading. The results from this research enable the development of reliable yet high-performance of micro-/nano-electromechanical systems and hence benefit the U.S. economy and society.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, the in situ high resolution transmission electron microscopy and atomistic molecular dynamics simulations have been applied to obtain fundamental knowledge of friction phenomena at the atomic scale between tungsten (W) single-asperity nano-contacts and grain boundary strutrual evolution in Au nanocrystals. Specifically, the notable results from this research are that: (1) The atomic friction between tungsten single asperities is found to display a discrete stick-slip behavior that the nanoscale tip chooses zigzag routine along <111> via two-steps to complete the friction along <110> direction; (2) Direct real-time observation of atomic-scale interfacial structure during frictional processes reveals the formation of a loosely packed interfacial layer between two metallic W asperities that enables a low friction under tensile; (3) The accumulation and release of strain energy on the atomic friction interface between W asperities is observed to undergo an asynchronous evolution, accompanied by the inhomogeneous strain/stress distribution and a non-uniform movement of interface atoms during the friction process; and (4) Our study reveals that the formation of a high angle grain boundary between two Au bi-crystals will undergo a process of accumulation, alignment, and exhaustion of geometrically necessary dislocations, whereas the annihilation of a high angle grain boundary between two Au bi-crystals is accomplished by synergic operation of grain boundary structure reconstruction, emission of partial and full dislocations, and twinning.

Broader Impacts: The project produces and disseminates new basic science knowledge of interface formation and atomic friction processes relevant to the performance and reliability of micro-/nano-electromechanical systems, and thus has an impact on a broad range of fields including renewable energy, automobile, aerospace and medical health, which demand advanced nanodevices for accurate sensing, timing and signal processing. The HRTEM and computation tools developed in this project have been distributed in academic community to study twining deformation in lightweight metal with a hexagonal closed packed crystal structure, deformation mechanism in high entropy alloys, and temperature-dependent mechanical behavior of metallic nanomaterials. Five research articles have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and multiple technical presentations have been delivered at international conferences. The research results have been added as teaching materials of graduate and undergraduate courses. Through the entire life of the award, four PhD graduate students and four undergraduate students receive the research training in experimental and computational materials science. Especially, this project supports a summer research internship under the Facilitating Inclusive Research Experience (FIRE) program, which is designed to encourage research experiences for undergraduates from traditionally underrepresented U.S. demographic groups. Moreover, the research results have been incorporated into curriculum enhancement, student training, industrial collaboration, and an educational outreach program.

 


Last Modified: 11/12/2023
Modified by: Guofeng Wang
